conclusion: Given a point charge +q at point A(0,0,h) and need to find the electric field at point P(h,h,-h) in the region z <= 0, filled with an infinite conductor.
Use the method of images to replace the conductor with an image charge that mimics the effect of the real charge.
Place an image charge -q at a symmetrical point across the conductor boundary z = 0, located at (0, 0, -h).
Let E1 be the electric field at point P due to the actual charge +q and E2 be the electric field at point P due to the image charge -q.
Calculate distance r1 from +q at A(0,0,h) to P(h,h,-h) as h√6.
Calculate distance r2 from -q at (0,0,-h) to P(h,h,-h) as h√2.
Calculate electric field magnitude due to +q at P as kq/6h^2.
Calculate electric field magnitude due to -q at P as kq/2h^2.
Direction of E1 is from +q to P and direction of E2 is from P to -q.
Consider components of E1 and E2 along the x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis.
Use symmetry and known results for image charges to find the resultant electric field magnitude.
Final expression for the magnitude of the resultant electric field is E = (kq/h^2)(1/√2 - 1/√6).
